sect2.title: Setting up ethernet cards
sect2.para: Ethernet cards can be configured with the Edit network configuration item that is available through the Network & Internet tab in Adminmenu.

sect2.title: Configuring DNS
sect2.para: DNS servers have a very special task in networking. They translate hostnames (for instance www.libranet.com) to IP addresses. To be able to use hostnames the system needs access to one or more DNS servers. Almost all Internet service providers provide DNS servers. DNS can be configured per interface via the Network configuration item in Adminmenu. To change the DNS server for an interface, select the network connection, and click on Edit connection properties. The DNS settings are then available under the DNS tab (). You can add a DNS server with the Add button, or remove the selected server with the Delete button.

sect1.title: Manual configuration
sect1.para: This chapter explains how some common network-related configuration files work. Most things can be configured with adminmenu, but more experienced users might prefer configuring things by editing the relevant configuration files.

sect2.title: Configuring nameservers
sect2.para: The name resolver is configured using the /etc/resolv.conf file. This file is dynamically generated, based on the interface settings. You manually add entries by editing /etc/resolvconf/resolv.conf.d/base Nameservers that should be used can be configured by adding a lines of the following form: nameserver <IP address>. sect2.title: Local hosts
sect2.para: Besides resolving using name servers specified in /etc/resolv.conf, GNU/Linux can also resolve hosts that are specified in /etc/hosts. This file is handy for adding names to local hosts, without the hassle of configuring a local name server. Hosts are specified in the following form: <IP address> <name1> ... <namen>. note.para: If you want to use the same hosts file on a relatively large number of machines, it might we worth looking at the dnsmasq package. Dnsmasq can provide a hosts file on one host to a complete network through its DNS server.
